metadata.h1: Doing Data Science with Python’s Built-in Statistics Library

all_paragraphs: Getting code running locally and then watching it fail in production is something we can all relate to. Particularly when the production environment is not completely under our control (ie: AWS Lambdas, Elastic Beanstalk…).
For that reason, I’m a believer in not introducing dependencies unless necessary. If a standard library can achieve a result, there’s no need to import something fancy.
While most data scientists rush for Scipy, Python contains a number of statistics function’s in its standard library. The question is whether it’s enough.
Let’s go on a tour through Python’s standard statistics library. We’ll import a dataset to play with and then walk through functions in statistics.
Then import the dataset we’re going to play with and drop it into a dataframe. The dataframe has nothing to do with statistics but makes it easier for us to look at.
The arithmetic mean. The sum of values in a set, divided by the number of values in that set. While it’s the most well known, it’s just one measure of the centre of a set of values.
It can also be highly misleading if the data is not balanced. For example, let’s compare the distribution of “Malic acid” in the dataset with it’s mean.
Notice how the mean is skewed up by a few outliers on the high end.
A quick way of thinking about harmonic mean is as a conservative average which gives extra weight to lower input values.
We use harmonic mean all the time when evaluating machine learning models. An f1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall.
In a model evaluation scenario with precision of 0.65 and recall of 0.8, we could use harmonic_mean to calculate the f1 score.
That said, we’d have to write our own functions to calculate precision and recall if we weren’t using sklearn to begin with.
The median is the middle value in an ordered set of data.
Median is interesting because it’s not as skewed up by a few large or tiny values in a set. For this reason, I always consider it important to look at in addition to arithmetic mean.
Median returns the middle number for a set with an odd number of values, and takes the average of the 2 middle values if the set has an even number of values.
Let’s look at “malic acid” again so we can see the difference between mean and median.
Almost exactly the same as median but it takes the lower middle number if the set has an odd number of values.
Takes the higher middle number if set has an odd number of values.
Finds the median of continuous classes where the width of each class is the size of the interval (interval=1, by default).
I’ve illustrated an example above that corresponds to the data we’re using the function on below.
Note how much easier it is to use the function than calculate it ourselves.
Returns the most frequent data point from a set.
A measure of the spread of data in a population.
The value will be large if the data is widely spread and small if the data is grouped around a point. It’s calculated as the square root of variance.
0.81 tells us the data is highly centered. It’s more apparent if we visualize it in a histogram and see alcohol levels entirely between 11 and 15.
Another measure of the spread of data.
But note it’s slightly more common to report on the standard deviation of the data as it’s more closely related to the mean.
It’s almost calculated exactly the same as the population standard deviation except that we use n-1 as the denominator instead of N. Khan Academy has a great video on why we do that, here.
We use this when calculating standard deviation on a sample instead of the population.
The variance we calculate on a sample instead of the total population. n-1 vs N applies the same here.
We have some useful functions in statistics, but it's clear that numpy and pandas blow it out of the water. That said, it doesn’t hurt to understand what Python can do out of the box.
Not everybody calculating statistics is doing data science and for working on an app, mean and standard deviation are probably more than enough.
That said, Python 3.8 added a few new functions I didn’t cover here so who knows what they’ll add in the future.
